results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film the ‘Walkabouters’ go to Werribee Gorge State Park in Victoria for one of their walks. On this visit, they see spiders, flowers and fungi, look for rock samples and do some fence making and tree planting.

A particular point of interest is an early Coolabah brand wine cask. Established in 1962, Orlando Coolabah was one of the first commercially successful cask wine brands in Australia and very popular in the 1970s. The wine cask itself was invented and perfected in Australia, initially by Angoves Wines in South Australia.

This film also shows some mushrooms and the practice of ‘mushrooming’ in grassy farm paddocks, equipped with buckets and knives.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:34:00 close-up of a moth on a leaf
00:00:38:00 large mushrooms in a grassy paddock
00:00:46:00 a woman slicing the mushrooms from the ground and collecting in a bucket
00:01:07:00 a largish spider runs up a canvas tent wall and the underside of a mushroom
00:01:22:00 peeling a large mushroom
00:01:52:00 a Coolabah brand wine cask and a poodle dog, mushrooms cooked on a camp stove
00:02:10:00 climbing over a stile in a fence
00:02:53:00 hikers climbing and helping each other over a rocky part of the trail
00:03:07:00 close-up of a spider in its web
00:04:07:00 descending a steep rock face
00:05:49:00 a iridescent blue and green beetle, tree lichen and a brown spider in its web
00:06:09:00 perfect light brown mushroom soon followed by another species of mushroom
00:06:54:00 several spiders on their webs
00:07:42:00 a variety of leather mushrooms
00:08:30:00 likely Ambicodamus crinitus spider
00:09:13:00 sign ‘Werribee Gorge’
00:09:30:00 hikers group sitting on the edge of a rocky cliff looking at the view, including a woman with binoculars
00:11:18:00 koala in close-up and and then climbing a tree
00:11:40:00 soaring Australian wedge-tailed eagle
00:12:07:00 group of (likely) bombadier beetles in green leaves
00:12:52:00 crossing the creek rock by rock
00:13:05:00 a small brown frog (likely litoria paraewingi)
00:13:12:00 hikers take a break - cameras, snacks and beer
00:15:02:00 overlooking tents at the camping site
00:15:17:00 wading the creek and a hiker rests with his dog on a hillside
00:15:55:00 leaf impressions on the rocks
00:16:36:00 1970s style cars - station wagons and camping van
00:16:55:00 two men using a manual post hole digger followed by scenes of fence making
00:17:29:00 planting new trees

results.title: [Orsola: Teramo, 1960]
results.brief_description:
In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico Ciabarra, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine. The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.
results.description:
A ‘day in the life’ of a young woman whose fiancé has emigrated to Melbourne, Australia. In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine.

The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia.

The related work “Innamorati” - made by Orsola’s daughter - tells the moving story of Orsola’s marriage and her journey to Australia to be reunited with her husband.
description_for_label:

results.title: [Darcy Prendergast's Light Pen Animation]
results.brief_description: Animator Darcy Prendergast was commissioned by ACMI to make some light-hearted works – representing film, TV and games – for display on screens throughout the ACMI building. Using his lightpen technique and combining computer animated movement with real-life locations, the films are a ‘hat-tip’ to the internationally popular feature films and characters of the Australian film industry.

results.title: In conversation with Chris Dercon and Kaat Debo
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This free talk was held at ACMI on 17 July 2013 to celebrate two exhibitions, ACMI’s ‘Hollywood Costume’ and RMIT University Design Hub’s ‘Walter Van Beirendonck; Dream the World Awake’.

Chris Dercon, director of London’s Tate Modern, and Kaat Debo, director/curator at Mode Museum in Antwerp, discussed the particulars of exhibiting fashion and costume, and explored the dialogue between art and fashion.

They investigated the ways a curator can animate clothes through multisensory and multimedia experiences, Dercon and Debo looked at the approaches taken by curators, identifying interesting narratives for exhibiting garments and took the audience behind-the-seams of fashion and costume exhibiting.
results.title_for_label: In conversation with Chris Dercon and Kaat Debo
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: Game Masters: an evening with Tetsuya Mizuguchi
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Jim Arneman, ACMI Screen Events and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Join music gaming legend, artist and auteur, Tetsuya Mizuguchi, as he plays some of his seminal games and speaks about his signatory sound and visual fusion.

Famed for his pioneering application of music and visuals, Mizuguchi uses music not just as an accompaniment to a game, but as an integral part of its gameplay. Including traditional videogames, such as the hugely successful ‘Sega Rally Championship’, Mizuguchi has worked on some of the most original and unconventional music-fusion titles, including ‘Space Channel 5’, ‘Lumines’, ‘Rez’ and his latest opus, ‘Child of Eden’.

During this hosted conversation Mizuguchi explores how his vision has evolved over his career and demonstrates his pioneering application of music and visuals through live gameplay.

results.title: Game Masters: Rob Murray interview
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Rob Murray speaks about his career as a game designer. Starting out as a solo developer for hire to becoming CEO of Firemint, Murray is one of the most successful indie game developers in existence.

Firemint’s success is due to Murray’s vision to create games such as ‘Flight Control’(2009) and’ Real Racing’ (2009), which are both easy to play and elegant and addictive in equal measure. In addition, his prescient reading of the drive towards personalised gaming, led by the ubiquity of social networking on mobile platforms, has kept his games on trend – ‘Flight Control’, for example, allows players to choose music from their personal libraries to accompany the game.

Rob talks about the rise of mobile based gaming and the development of ‘Flight Control’ and ‘Real Racing’ .

results.title: Game Masters: Hideo Kojima interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Hideo Kojima speaks about his career as a designer and producer of video games at Konami Digital Entertainment and Kojima Productions. At a time when mainstream action games only focused on attack and defeat, ‘METAL GEAR’ (1987) introduced infiltration into the gameplay and became one of the earliest examples of a stealth game. In 1998, the first 3D title in the ‘Metal Gear’ series, ‘METAL GEAR SOLID’, was released, integrating the most advanced stealth-based gameplay yet seen with cut-scenes that reflected Kojima’s passion for cinema. ‘METAL GEAR SOLID’ became a worldwide best seller and was followed by three successful sequels.

NB: This interview was conducted in Hideo Kojima’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Fumito Ueda interview
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Fumito Ueda may have only two published games but each one has had such an impact that his influence is felt keenly across the industry. Ueda joined Sony Computer Entertainment in 1997 where he developed his first game, ‘ICO’ (2001), a beautifully poetic adventure game based on an abstracted boy-meets-girl premise. Ueda’s next game, ‘Shadow of the Colossus’ (2005) took an opposing theme to ICO’s sacrificial narrative, with the aim being to topple 16 giant mythical beings to restore the life of a girl named Mono.

NB: This interview was conducted in Fumito Ueda’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Yu Suzuki interview
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Yu Suzuki talks about his body of work which is one of the most diverse in the industry, ranging from the adrenalin rushes of his early arcade hits ‘Space Harrier’ (1985) and ‘Hang-On’ (1985) to the console adventure epic ‘Shenmue’ (1999).

As the pioneer of immersive, full-body arcade games, Suzuki has never been afraid to explore fantasy, reality and every shade of virtual experience in between.

In 1999, Suzuki moved away from arcades to create ‘Shenmue’ (1999), an open-world adventure for the Dreamcast. ‘Shenmue’ was recognised at the time as one of the most expansive and detailed videogames ever made; it pioneered the ‘open city’ subgenre of open-world games.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Greenhalgh, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.description:
Yu Suzuki talks about his body of work which is one of the most diverse in the industry, ranging from the adrenalin rushes of his early arcade hits ‘Space Harrier’ (1985) and ‘Hang-On’ (1985) to the console adventure epic ‘Shenmue’ (1999).

As the pioneer of immersive, full-body arcade games, Suzuki has never been afraid to explore fantasy, reality and every shade of virtual experience in between.

In 1999, Suzuki moved away from arcades to create ‘Shenmue’ (1999), an open-world adventure for the Dreamcast. ‘Shenmue’ was recognised at the time as one of the most expansive and detailed videogames ever made; it pioneered the ‘open city’ subgenre of open-world games.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Alex Rigopulos and Eran Egozy interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Alex Rigopulos and Eran Egozy talk about their careers designing games at Harmonix Music Systems. While not the first to combine music and videogames, Rigopulos and Egozy were central to the global success of the rhythm genre.

Rigopulos and Egozy’s studio Harmonix’s first two rhythm games, the cult classics ‘Frequency’ (2001) and ‘Amplitude’ (2003), were abstract games with trance-like visuals matched to a gameplay of tight precision. They soon moved on to peripheral-based rhythm games such as ‘Guitar Hero’ (2005), ‘Rock Band’ (2007) and ‘Dance Central’ (2010).

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.
